title: (x) Government of Canada - Neue Helvetica {Chesh, Grant}
content: Looks like Helvetica to me, though that sample is awfully small.
author: cheshiredave

comments.content:
Helvetica Neue Medium.   
   
Here's a fairly standard wordmark enlarged from a government-supplied Adobe Illustrator file.   
   
 ![Government of Canada](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516142325im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/24794.gif)

\> _What happened to that classy Baskerville Old Face mark?_   
   
You mean this beauty? Oh, it still gets kicked around the various hallways of bureaucracy. The Baskerville mark is basically the government's happy, shiny corporate logo, whereas the Helvetica Neue treatments are departmental identifiers. You can get your fill of Canadian government logos, symbols, word marks, and assorted style guides here:   
   
 [http://icnet.ic.gc.ca/publication/](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516142325/http:/icnet.ic.gc.ca/publication/)   
   
 ![Government of Canada word mark](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516142325im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/24878.gif)

Here's my favourite of the bunch, the [Federal Identity Program](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516142325/http:/www.tbs-sct.gc.ca/fip-pcim/man_e.asp), complete with before and after comparisons of 'recent' updates. Be sure to check out the nearly [70MB worth](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516142325/http:/www.tbs-sct.gc.ca/fip-pcim/man_pdfs_e.asp) of downloadable PDF fun as well.

I did a double take when I saw those coats of arms--I thought they were V-8 engines at first.   
   
 ![v-8s](http://web.archive.org/web/20050516142325im_/http:/www.typophile.com/forums/messages/83/24890.jpg)
